body:
Ok, lets rename to akey.
Could you update your PR?
Realized this is already fixed on master.  Checked wrong branch when I forked.

I should have forked from master instead of ignite-1.5.7, but issue appears to still exist on master as well.  Not sure if this was intentional for performance reasons, but master is aggregating swap and off heap sizes, so I would assume the intention would be to aggregate size as well.

Thanks for the contribution!

However, please create a JIRA ticket in Apache Ignite JIRA, make a fork against master, add all required additional tests that will validate the fix and after that open the pull request one more time.
To get familiar with our dev process refer to this doc
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/IGNITE/How+to+Contribute#HowtoContribute-1.CreateGitHubpull-request
Created new branch and PR based on ignite-1.6 branch instead of master. See https://github.com/apache/ignite/pull/700

I merged into ignite-1.6 and master.
ignite-1.6 will be released by the end of May
Thanks.

I merged this to master. Please close the PR.

Saikat, many thanks for contributing this! There were some changes from my side on review. Please take a look.

Ryan, please close the PR.

I have merged this to master. Thanks for your contribution!
Thanks for contributing this. I have merged this to master. Please close the PR
Thank you Yakov. I will close the PR.
Merged into ignite-1.6 and master branches.
@agoncharuk  Would you please help me to review this PR?
Yes, you can change it in such a way because you just rename method's parameter "gridName" to "instanceName".

@lftrevisan I've updated the Dockerfile following the Best Practices https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/eng-image/dockerfile_best-practices/.

The resulting size was reduced from 1.061 GB to 885 MB.

Also output from `docker history apacheignite/ignite:1.6.0`:


Nice job. Is it possible to use a jre base image instead of the jdk version?

Using JRE base image should be fine, unless someone from Apache Ignite developers know the reason why the full JDK is required (to support zero deployment? or JRE would be sufficient as well?). 

At least the official Getting Started doc says "Apache Ignite was officially tested on: Oracle JDK 7 and above". So the docker image is already based on non-tested open JDK, so maybe better stay with it, at least some guarantee.

Hi Kristian,

Thanks for the contribution! I've slightly modified your initial pull-request and merged it into the master branch.
closing because this targets ignite-1.5 branch

Seems patch has a bug in GridResourceProcessor.injectToJob method: try to inject GridResourceIoc.AnnotationSet.TASK resources instead of GridResourceIoc.AnnotationSet.JOB resources.
Fixed in #946

Thanks for pointing to rmvIdx!
Yes, we have faced the same problem. Is IGNITE-3809 is a duplicate of the same issue? I cannot find it on JIRA.

Title seems to be confusing. 
You obviously mean "Make single Cleanup worker for all GridCacheTtlManager".
@AMashenkov, you are right. I just used name of corresponding jira issue (professional habit). But I'm not sure is it acceptable to change PR/issue names at this moment..
Sorry, test is ok. But I can't to reproduce test failure on x86. Do you use different arch to run test?

Hi,@amartianov

Have you tested this patch under load. I have the same issues and want to hear from you.
Thanks for putting effort into resolving this issue! Approximately when do you think this branch will be merged and released?

Hi John!

Thank you for your contribution! I have just had a chance to reivew it.

First question. Why did you file this issue? Was there a discussion on dev list? Can you porvide a link if any?

I fixed some naming/formatting issues in GridCacheRebalancingAggregationTest and pushed everything to ignite-3897-pr1059. Please review and consider going furhter.

As far as GridCacheRebalancingAggregationTest - it obviously has a bug. If on some random iteration update thread throws exception, test does not fail. This should fail the test for sure.

As a general note I would say that when you dealing with restart/failover tests one thread doing updates is not enough. You should send massive and variable load to your tests topology from multiple threads prefferrably having contended keys between them.

I would aslo encourage you to take a look at our current failover threads. It seems we already have tests of the kind:
IgniteCacheCrossCacheTxFailoverTest
GridCacheTxNodeFailureSelfTest
etc

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Hi Yakov,
Thank you for the feedback - I will look at ignite-3897-pr1059 and update this PR with the changes, and also look at the failure of GridCacheRebalancingAggregationTest to fail on Exception - thank you for spotting that.

Just a little background - these restart tests began with https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IGNITE-3789 - these tests `kill -9 <pid>` a node in the grid, rather than sending a Callable to shut down nodes gracefully. We find that this type of test can uncover unusual/unintended behaviours. 

 IgniteCacheCrossCacheTxFailoverTest and GridCacheTxNodeFailureSelfTest don't override `GridAbstractTest.isMultiJvm()` to start external processes for testing, and GridAbstractTest doesn't currently have the ability to kill nodes - this ability was added in GridRollingRestartAbstractTest#stopGrid(int idx)

If these new tests we're adding are duplicating the existing failover tests, perhaps I could modify the existing tests so they start nodes as separate processes and randomly stop nodes with `kill -9` instead of a graceful `stop` callable? Or perhaps I can keep these as a distinct type of failover test, and I will try to reuse the existing tests - simply run them in the context of a grid undergoing "RollingRestart" (which is achieved by subclassing GridRollingRestartAbstractTest).

Let me know what you think would be the best way to get test coverage in this area (whether by reusing GridRollingRestartAbstractTest, or modifying the existing failover tests to allow them to be run while a rolling restart is in progress). 
Thanks!
John

Great, 
Now looks good to me

Hi @yzhdanov , I've merged your review feedback into the branch. I added code to ensure the update thread logs any exceptions and also the test checks that the thread exited without encountering an exception. 

If the updateThread exited, either `while (restartThread.isAlive());` or an exception occurred, so the test that `assertEquals(getMaxRestarts(), restartThread.getRestartTotal());` was trying to ensure that updateThread exited due to restartThread/test finishing, rather than an exception - but I've made it test explicitly that the updateThread hasn't encountered an exception - it's much cleaner/clearer this way, thanks for questioning it. 

Cheers
John
Posted this in the Jira too, but just in case it's lost there: what's the update on this issue? Will it be integrated into Ignite 1.8.0? I'd like to stop maintaining my own Ignite branch :)

For this implementation to be reviewed, please specify JIRA issue number.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IGNITE

Main notices for now:
- Move everything you've added to `IgniteH2Indexing` to separate component like `DmlExecutor`.
- `SqlSplitter` should not be touched at all.
It also makes sense to wait until all other feature branches will be merged to master.

@svladykin,

Regarding some of your comments:
1. Use assertEquals(a, b) instead of assert a.eaquals(b) in all tests
   **There are no keyword based assertions in any new tests that this branch introduces. Please specify where exactly you found those.**
2. JdbcPreparedStatement.executeBatch must throw unsupported exception
   **Done, removed tests as well.**
3. JdbcPreparedStatement.ensureArgsSize: if we know exact number of parameters from getNativeStatement(), then we have to check parameter index here.
   **We don't know exact number of params here - PreparedStatement interface does not give that number and H2 library is not among dependencies of ignite-core, therefore we can't cast to H2's JdbcPreparedStatement either.**
4. JdbcQueryTask constuctor: why locQry became Boolean?
   **Typo, fixed.**
5. JdbcStatement.updateCounterFromQueryResult and updateCnt always use long internally, convert to int if public API needs int.
   **Done.**
6. Avoid using UUID.randomUUID()
   **Could you please elaborate on this? JdbcStatement has been using randomUUID for a long time, nothing new added here. And besides that, the only uses of randomUUID I see in this diff are in tests.**
7. executeBatch have to throw SQLFeatureNotSupportedException
   **Done, removed test as well.**
8. QueryCursorImpl.isResSet rename to isQry **Done.**
9. QueryCursorImpl.forUpdateResult: itemCnt must be long, fieldsMeta must not be empty **Done.**
10. IgniteSQLException.toJdbcException: always wrap getCause() to another SQLException **Done.**

The rest is WIP.
Also lets change `UUID.randomUUID()` to `IgniteUuid.randomUuid()` in V2 jdbc task.
why do u have so many commits in one pull request??
Thanks for your comment. I've fixed the base branch

Closing this due to releasing DML streaming feature via different branch. New pull request:

https://github.com/apache/ignite/pull/1553
please, make sure there are no conflicts.
Closing.  The PR contains changes from multiple branches...I hate Git.

God please, you see this "pull request" and please merge in "master" branch.
Amen.
![amen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8217718/24969688/402cdc6c-1fba-11e7-908b-e857c5cbccf4.jpg)

"why didn't we see the correct error message down the stack?" - because the wrapper exception is itself wrapped, and so is done several times. If user have long enough space to see the full stack trace, he has a chance to see original error message down the stack, but in most cases, the system trims stack trace to reasonable size and deletes the bottom part with the original error message.
@shroman  Have you design wiki for this feature ?
